messages: 86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:37): so since rip auto-summarizes and you can't turn that off, i've been running a network where routing would fail and routes would get summarizes that packets might get through to the same classful network on the *other* side. how come everything worked fine?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:38): that was gibberish
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:38): welcome to classful networking
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:39): you are not supposed to subnet to muliple sizes (VLSM)

86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:39): but how come everything works. as in end hosts can reach end hosts in the same classful network even though they're separated by a different classful network?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:40): I understand!
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:40): i can subnet with classful routing
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:40): i just must choose my size everywhere
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:40): nemith, do you remember when I said that rip couldn't find a secondary route to a failed link?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:40): well that's because of summarization!!
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:41): the routing protocol will assume that if it has a route in the same ip class that the prefix on the other side is the same length
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:41): that's why my routers couldn't *build* another route from the table to make up for the one that just went down
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:41): it's not summerizing
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:41): summerization is a VLSM term
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:42): well it's *not summarizing*
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:43): ok i'm getting confused
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:43): i need to think about this
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:44): it doesn't know the prefix length (the subnet mask)
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:44): ok, rip summarizes by default
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:44): and that can't be changed to its nature. no a vlsm-aware protocol
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:45): so lets say i am a router with 192.168.0.10/24 on E1 and 172.16.0.1/30 on S0
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:46): if router B on the other side of S0 has an interface 10.3.1.0/24 and it send it to me
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:46): i get 10.3.1.0  no subnet-mask.. since i don't have a local interface in the 10.0.0.0/8 (whtich is th class)
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:47): i assume you have the entire class and change the route from 10.3.10 to 10.0.0.0/8
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:47): so router A wouldn't take any 192.168.0.0 or any 172.16.0.0 route right?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:48): doesn't it think that it own the classful networks?
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:48): so lets say on router A i have 192.168.0.1/28
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:48): router B send the route to router a
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:48): whoops bad example
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:49): it would be in the routing table as 192.16.128.0 as that is the size of the class
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:49): didn't you say you got 55% in rip? lol
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:49): wipe the slate clean
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:50): when A get the route it is 10.8.0.0
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:50): router A assume that since they are in the same class that you chose one size to subnet everything
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:51): so it installs the route as 10.8.0.0/28
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:51): oh so A adverts that it owns 10.8.0.0?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:51): even though it belongs to via B?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:52): as far as it was explained to me, router A thinks that 10.0.0.0 belongs to him and router B things that 10.0.0.0 belongs to him!
b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (08:52): sup folks
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:52): it doesn't matter
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (08:53): rewinding back to when you said "and not 16"
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:54): so when doing classful routing we are assuming that if we subnet we are all going to use the same prefix-length
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:55): so if i have a 10.x.x.x/16 on router a.. i should have 10.x.x.x/16 on router b
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:55): the router makes this assumption since ripv1 doesn't support rip
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:57): the real problem is where you have a classful router that is discontiguous
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:58): rotuer A and router C have a 10.x.0.0/16 route,  they both get to each other through router B
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:58): router B doesn't have a 10.0.0.0 address
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:58): it gets two routes for 10.1.0.0 and 10.2.0.0 it assume both are the entire class
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:59): and puts both of them in the routing table as 10.0.0.0/8
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (08:59): this is why classful routing sucks so bad
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:01): did tkup ever specify he was running RIPv1 rather than RIPv2?  I wasn't paying attention
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:02): so what happens when b puts the whole 10.0 in its routing table?
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:02): ripv2 is ok. it support vlsm
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (09:03): it's still horible
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (09:03): tkup: it will have equal hops for 10.0.0.0/8 to both router A and router B
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (09:03): and only half of destined packets will get there
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:03): yeah, every time someone uses RIP a fairy dies.
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:04): i thought it was still being used at the border?
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (09:07): it's used for some legacy unix servers
b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:08): LOL... a fairy dies...  omg that was great
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:09): i'm using rip on my obsd router within the cisco lab
5413d900581bd6546043f95aae132a3f (09:10): well, get past that chapter and start using ospf
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:10): lol
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:11): I just took my CCNA again recently and every other question was about EIGRP anyway
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:11): spanning tree and EIGRP was 2/3 the exam
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:12): yeah i need to move on now
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:12): Just know that RIPv1 and IGRP are classful, and what metrics they use and that's pretty much it. :)
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:12): so in calculating metrics, K5=0, but if you look at the formula if K5=0 the whole computation goes to zero :/
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:13): Metric = [K1 * Bandwidth + (K2 * Bandwidth)/(256-load) + K3*Delay] * [K5/(reliability + K4)]
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:13): so if K5=0 it's 0 * [K1 * Bandwidth + (K2 * Bandwidth)/(256-load) + K3*Delay] which is zero
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:14): then that becomes 1*bandwidth + 1*delay
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:15): it's actually 0 * [1*bandwidth + 1*delay]
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:15): oh wait, * 0.. err
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:16): but then a cisco article says this: "if K5 = 0, the [K5/(reliability + K4)] term is not used"
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:16): you studying for CCNA?
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:16): I don't think you need to know all that either
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:16): lol
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:16): but building some foundation for possibly ccnp
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:16): yeah, get CCNP
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:17): can't you take one of the CCNP exams to "recertify"?
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:17): can't really do a whole lot with skills learned from CCNA alone
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:17): Yeah, passing a CCNP exam recerts the CCNA
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:17): or so Tabularasa told me
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:18): which I would assume is correct, since he did it
86ec35b554365c4bc12a4d4571e0e152 (09:18): so why don't you take one of the ccnps instead of the ccna over?
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:18): I let it expire accidentally
b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:19): i did the same thing...
b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:19): frggin 3 years crept up me quick

62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:19): I got into Cisco stuff a while back, and then went back to being a systems admin like I had been before, and only recently had the opportunity to become a network admin once again.
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:20): And then when I went to check the old CCNA, it had expired like 9 months before, haha
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:20): It's ok, the CCNA has matured a lot since I took it the first time.
62d3bfcdd93fab66c58ed4866fac9ee5 (09:21): Wasn't crap on it way back when

b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:21): month*

b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:22): yeah... it's deffinitely a challenge

b7fea7efac9d64ae7568440d4f1d96d2 (09:23): im just counting on taking the lab twice.  hehe...  but who knows.
